item.title: Greece Hit by General Strike to Protest Austerity
item.description: The nationwide walkout came as Parliament prepared to debate an array of new economic reforms needed to obtain rescue loans.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS
item.media:description: Greek workers went on strike on Tuesday to protest government plans to fire thousands of public sector employees.

item.title: At War Blog: A Problematic Genre, the ‘Kill Memoir’
item.description: The promotional campaign for the book “Carnivore” represents the latest and most extreme iteration of a troublesome publishing phenomenon.
item.category: No Easy Day: The Firsthand Account of the Mission That Killed Osama bin Laden (Book)
item.dc:creator: By BRIAN VAN REET
item.media:description: The author, Brian Van Reet, in Baghdad in 2005.

item.title: Prosecutors Raid Home of Former South Korean President
item.description: The former president, Chun Doo-hwan, had been under a Supreme Court ruling to repay money it said he had illegally accumulated in the 1980s.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Letter from China: Play Tests China's Sexual Limits
item.description: "Our Vaginas, Ourselves," which addresses everything from masturbation to abortion, is showing at small, unofficial venues across the country.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: India Ink: Hyderabad Debates Health Insurance Model As Public Hospitals Decay
item.description: As India’s public hospitals struggle with decaying infrastructure, Andhra Pradesh debates a populist health insurance program.
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN COX
item.media:description: A person, injured in the bomb blast, at a hospital in Hyderabad, Andhra Pradesh, on Feb. 21.

item.title: 7 People Die and Hundreds Are Injured in Cairo Clashes
item.description: After days without major violence, clashes broke out between Islamists and the police, leaving seven dead, injuring more than 200 and highlighting growing political disaffection.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: A supporter of former President Mohamed Morsi in Cairo on Tuesday.

item.title: South Korea Blames North for June Cyberattacks
item.description: The cyberattacks paralyzed 69 Web sites last month, including those belonging to the South Korea’s president and local media companies.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Australian Leader Scraps Tax on Carbon Emissions
item.description: Prime Minister Kevin Rudd of Australia announced a plan to replace a deeply unpopular tax on carbon emissions with a market-based trading system a year ahead of schedule.
item.dc:creator: By MATT SIEGEL

item.title: Korean Steel Maker Shelves Plan for $5.3 Billion Mill in India
item.description: Local opposition and the slow pace of acquiring land and licenses led Posco to end the project in the Indian state of Karnataka, the company said.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Panama Seizes North Korea-Flagged Ship for Weapons
item.description: The ship was apparently headed from Cuba to North Korea and officials said the illicit cargo was hidden behind sugar.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY

item.title: India Ink: A Small Town Near Gurgaon Wrestles With Change
item.description: As Gurgaon swells, a farming village morphs into a small town.
item.dc:creator: By ASGAR QADRI
item.media:description: A residential apartment tower belonging to the Bestech Group in Dharuhera, Haryana, on July 9.

item.title: Clashes Return to Streets of Cairo in Another Blow for Egypt
item.description: More than 20 people were reported injured as the Egyptian police and protesters clashed in Cairo early Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Drug Kingpin Is Captured in Mexico Near Border
item.description: The capture of Miguel Ángel Treviño Morales, the leader of the Zetas drug cartel, was a retort from Mexico’s government to questions over whether it would go after top organized crime leaders.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

item.title: Parliament Votes to Indict Ex-Official in Greece
item.description: Greek lawmakers voted to indict former Finance Minister George Papaconstantinou over the way he handled a list of Greeks with Swiss accounts, a possible source of tax-revenue.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: Merkel Urges Europe to Tighten Internet Safeguards
item.description: The remarks by Germany’s chancellor, Angela Merkel, reflected the anger in Europe over accounts of government surveillance by the United States National Security Agency, leaked by Edward J. Snowden.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY and JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: Germany’s chancellor, Angela Merkel, is asking the European Union to require Internet companies to disclose their practices.

item.title: Seinajoki Journal: Finnish Tango: The Passion and the Melancholy
item.description: Every July, the Finnish town of Seinajoki draws thousands of people to a four-day tango festival, and many say the dance’s blend of passion and brooding perfectly expresses the Finnish soul.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN TAGLIABUE
item.media:credit: Touko Hujanen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tango dancers at the Seinajoki festival. Many here say the tango’s blending of passion and brooding perfectly expresses the Finnish soul.

item.title: U.S. Warns Egypt’s Generals Against Jeopardizing ‘Second Chance’ at Democracy
item.description: Deputy Secretary of State William J. Burns arrived in Cairo on Monday at a time when both sides of Egypt’s crisis have exhibited strong anti-American sentiment.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: Deputy Secretary of State William J. Burns met with Egypt's interim president, Adli Mansour, in Cairo on Monday.

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: Attacks Kill 9 People
item.description: Attacks across Iraq killed nine people on Monday, including a 10-year-old boy, the latest in a surge of violence rocking Iraq during the Muslim holy month of Ramadan.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: After Jet Crash, Asiana Airlines Will Bolster Its Pilot Training
item.description: The airline said it would give special safety training, including an enhanced program for visual approaches and automated flight, after the crash of an Asiana jet in San Francisco.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN and MATTHEW L. WALD

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Senator’s Slur Criticized
item.description: Calls mounted Monday for the resignation of the Senate’s vice president, Roberto Calderoli, after he compared Italy’s first black cabinet minister to an orangutan.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Protest at Nuclear Plant
item.description: Greenpeace activists occupied a French nuclear power plant site before dawn on Monday — a media stunt that embarrassed the government.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Captive in Mali Is Dead
item.description: The death of a Frenchman held by Islamist fighters in northern Africa was confirmed on Monday after the recovery and examination of the man’s body in northern Mali.
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SAYARE

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Congo: Army Shells Rebels
item.description: The Democratic Republic of Congo’s army shelled rebels on Monday in a second day of fierce fighting, and Rwanda and Congo traded accusations of aggression.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Myanmar Admits to Political Prisoners, Pledging Their Freedom
item.description: President U Thein Sein promised to free political prisoners that remained incarcerated as Myanmar emerges from a prolonged era of isolation and repression.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: The Lede: Comparing Black Minister to an Orangutan Was Not Racist, Italian Senator Insists
item.description: A senior Italian senator insists that it was “an aesthetic judgment, not meant to be racist,” when he said that Italy’s first black minister looked like an ape.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: Roberto Calderoli, the vice president of Italy's senate and a leader of the anti-immigrant Northern League party, at a news conference in 2011.
